Award.AwardTitle: CIF:Small:RUI: Mathematical Problems in Space-Time Block Codes for MIMO Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator studies mathematical problems that arise in coding and decoding for multiple-input-multiple-out (MIMO) wireless communications systems. Such communication systems promise much higher rates of data transfer with much higher fidelity than traditional single input/output systems, and the problems that the PI studies are of direct relevance to the design of such multiple input/output systems.

There are three broad classes of problems the research will focus on. The first class deals with issues in fast decoding of space-time block codes. One can speed up decoding by incorporating decoding considerations directly into the design of the code, or, one can also design approximate decoding schemes that will take advantage of the algebraic nature of the codes. Both routes throw up challenging mathematical issues, and the investigator studies various solutions to these. The second class of problems deals with the design of coset codes for slow fading channels. This project studies several problems that arise in this context, including determination of all possible quotients, appropriate choice of codes over finite rings, and importantly, appropriate choice of metric on the code over the quotient ring. The third class of problems deals with the design of codes for the wiretap channel. Here, the investigator studies a lattice conjecture for the Gaussian channel, then moves on to consider the design of codes for the MIMO wiretap channel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved investigation of three broad questions in mathematical coding theory, an area of research in wireless communication. One question concerned the design parameters for a strategy call "fast decoding" for space-time codes, another involved a mathematical conjecture arising from security considerations in a special type of channel called "wiretap channel," and the third involved the construction of "coset codes" for slow fading channel.

The principal investigator (PI) was able to make substantial contributions to the first two questions he studied. The PI, working with collaborators, did a thorough study of bounds on fast decodability and derived some fundamental results that showed that fast-decodability has severe limitations. The PI (and collaborators) showed that for full rate transmission (number of complex symbols $n^2$ for $nXn$ marices), the decoding complexity using fast-decodability cannot be better than $|S|^{n^2+1}$ where $|S|$ is the size of the effective real signal set. He showed that for full-rate transmission, $g$ group decodability is not possible. He showed that even if we relax full-rate transmission condition, the maximum number of groups possible using fast-decodability is only $4$. Finally, the PI showed that even with the maximum of $4$ groups, the maximum code rate possible is a constant $2$, which therefore does not grow with $n$. All these results put together show that fast-decodability as a technique has serious mathematical barriers to being effective.

As for the second question, the primary goal was to prove (or disprove) a certain mathematical conjecture concerning certain security parameters of "lattice codes," known as the Belifiore-Sole-Oggier conjecture. The PI (again with another collaborator) showed that this conjecture is \textit{false} for $l$-modular lattices when $l\neq 1$. The PI also suggested a different form of the conjecture that should hold when $l \neq 1$. 

The PI teaches in a comprehensive public university with a Masters program (but no PhD program). As part of this project, the PI was able to train two Masters degree students. Both students did their MS thesis on questions related to this project, and were able to prove substantial results. One student presented her work at an international conference in Turkey, while the work of the second student attracted interest of other mathematicians in Finland who went on to do further work on some conjectures she had made in her thesis. 

The PI is pleased to report that funds from this project were used for outreach to local area schools. The PI worked with the Pasadena Community Foundation to run two special math camps during Summer 2018 for gifted middle school students in the Pasadena school district. This was part of a special program called Math Academy in the district that targets gifted children even during the regular academic year. We ran two camps: one on Cryptography for 6th graders, and one on Coding Theory for 7th and 8th graders. There were a total of 42 students in the two camps, and they met over a five week period. They were led through the basics of Cryptography (respectively Coding Theory) by a teacher in the Math Academy and a Caltech graduate student. Two photographs from the summer camp are attached.
